title: Hypothemycin, a fungal natural product, identifies therapeutic targets in <italic>Trypanosoma brucei</italic>
abstract: Protein kinases are potentially attractive therapeutic targets for neglected parasitic diseases, including African trypanosomiasis caused by the protozoan, <italic>Trypanosoma brucei</italic>. How to prioritize <italic>T. brucei</italic> kinases and quantify their intracellular engagement by small-molecule inhibitors remain unsolved problems. Here, we combine chemoproteomics and RNA interference to interrogate trypanosome kinases bearing a Cys-Asp-Xaa-Gly motif (CDXG kinases). We discovered that hypothemycin, a fungal polyketide previously shown to covalently inactivate a subset of human CDXG kinases, kills <italic>T. brucei</italic> in culture and in infected mice. Quantitative chemoproteomic analysis with a hypothemycin-based probe revealed the relative sensitivity of endogenous CDXG kinases, including <italic>Tb</italic>GSK3short and a previously uncharacterized kinase, <italic>Tb</italic>CLK1. RNAi-mediated knockdown demonstrated that both kinases are essential, but only <italic>Tb</italic>CLK1 is fully engaged by cytotoxic concentrations of hypothemycin in intact cells. Our study identifies <italic>Tb</italic>CLK1 as a therapeutic target for African trypanosomiasis and establishes a new chemoproteomic tool for interrogating CDXG kinases in their native context.
